body: We use it to "intern" strings in the AST so every name is stored exactly once. This saves around 35% on a typical file. E.g. parsing all toxcore/*.c files together takes up 9,961,472 bytes with interning, and would take 15,335,424 bytes without interning. It takes 20,971,520 bytes with String instead of Text (with sharing - without sharing it takes 21,790,720 bytes). Also, for comparison: check-cimple takes around 0.25 seconds to parse all those files to `Node String`. Then it takes about 5ms (0.005s) to intern all the strings. We then store the entire AST in a contiguous block of memory, which would take 150ms if we didn't preserve sharing (so the interning we did would be useless), but actually takes about 1 second (1000ms) to produce a contiguous data structure of around 10MiB. Time spent in parsing and preparing the AST for analysis is thus around 1.2 seconds. We may later decide that this is not worth it since we're not a long-running application and would likely never benefit from the reduced GC pressure, and cache locality is unlikely to be much better than with a regular GC'd data structure. It's an interesting experiment, though :). --- This change isâ€‚[](https://reviewable.io/reviews/toktok/hs-tokstyle/42)

commit.message:
Generate a parse tree (AST) from the cimple parser.

We don't use it yet, and it's less strongly typed than it probably should
be, but it's a start, and can be used for pretty-printing and some simple
analyses.

Generate a parse tree (AST) from the cimple parser.

We don't use it yet, and it's less strongly typed than it probably should
be, but it's a start, and can be used for pretty-printing and some simple
analyses.

commit.message:
Add Traversable instance for the AST.

We use it to "intern" strings in the AST so every name is stored exactly
once. This saves around 35% on a typical file. E.g. parsing all
toxcore/*.c files together takes up 9,961,472 bytes with interning, and
would take 15,335,424 bytes without interning. It takes 20,971,520 bytes
with String instead of Text (with sharing - without sharing it takes
21,790,720 bytes).

Also, for comparison: check-cimple takes around 0.25 seconds to parse all
those files to `Node String`. Then it takes about 5ms (0.005s) to intern
all the strings. We then store the entire AST in a contiguous block of
memory, which would take 150ms if we didn't preserve sharing (so the
interning we did would be useless), but actually takes about 1 second
(1000ms) to produce a contiguous data structure of around 10MiB.

Time spent in parsing and preparing the AST for analysis is thus around
1.2 seconds. We may later decide that this is not worth it since we're
not a long-running application and would likely never benefit from the
reduced GC pressure, and cache locality is unlikely to be much better
than with a regular GC'd data structure. It's an interesting experiment,
though :).

Add Traversable instance for the AST.

We use it to "intern" strings in the AST so every name is stored exactly
once. This saves around 35% on a typical file. E.g. parsing all
toxcore/*.c files together takes up 9,961,472 bytes with interning, and

Also, for comparison: check-cimple takes around 0.25 seconds to parse all

memory, which would take 150ms if we didn't preserve sharing (so the

(1000ms) to produce a contiguous data structure of around 10MiB.

Time spent in parsing and preparing the AST for analysis is thus around
1.2 seconds. We may later decide that this is not worth it since we're
not a long-running application and would likely never benefit from the
reduced GC pressure, and cache locality is unlikely to be much better
than with a regular GC'd data structure. It's an interesting experiment,
though :).
